questions.text: Which muscle type is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Multipennate The image shows the pectoralis major muscle. The pectoralis major muscle is classified as multipennate, not unipennate. Multipennate muscles have multiple tendons with muscle fibers that branch out diagonally in a feather-like pattern from the central tendon. The pectoralis major has several tendons with muscle fibers extending in different directions, giving it a multipennate arrangement.
 

Other options: -

Option 1: Cruciate: Muscle fibres are arranged in X shape. Ex:- Sternocleidomastoid

Option 3: Parallel: Muscle fibres in these muscle run parallel to the length of muscle. Ex:- Biceps brachi

Option 4: Unipennate: Muscle fibres are arranged on one side of tendon. Ex:- Extensor digitorum

Reference : Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,41st Edition - page no.112

questions.text: From where are the branchial arch nerves derived?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Neural crest The branchial arch nerves are derived from the neural crest, which is a group of cells that form during embryonic development. The neural crest cells migrate to different parts of the body, where they differentiate into a variety of tissues, including the branchial arch nerve. The branchial arch nerves, such as the trigeminal nerve (CN V), facial nerve (CN VII), glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), and vagus nerve (CN X), are derived from the neural crest cells that populate the respective branchial arches.

 

Reference: Langman' Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 286

questions.text: What is the vocal cord tensor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Cricothyroid
 
  • The cricothyroid muscle is the only muscle that can tense the vocal cords.
  • The cricothyroid muscle connects the cricoid cartilage (a ring-shaped cartilage) to the thyroid cartilage (an anteriorly located cartilage in the larynx).
  • It does this by pulling the cricoid cartilage forward, which increases the distance between the vocal processes of the arytenoid cartilages.

questions.text: Where does the ureteric bud grow from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Mesonephros The ureteric bud (metanephric diverticulum) is an outgrowth from the mesonephric duct, which is derived from the mesonephros. The mesonephros is an intermediate stage in kidney development and serves as a temporary functional kidney during early embryonic development. The ureteric bud arises from the mesonephros and plays a crucial role in the development of the permanent kidney, or metanephros.

questions.text: Newly erupted teeth are covered by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is (2) Nasmyth's membrane

Nasmyth's membrane (also called enamel cuticle) is a thin, delicate tissue covering the enamel of newly erupted teeth. It is derived from the reduced enamel epithelium. It protects the tooth temporarily after eruption and is eventually worn away by mastication and cleaning. It is produced by the ameloblast cells.

Other options

Option 1 - Perikymata -  They refer to the wave like transverse ridges or grooves on the enamel surface caused by rhythmic enamel deposition. They are part of enamel surface topography, not a covering

Option 3 -Fibrous tissue - refers to the gingivial connective tissue - not a covering for enamel on teeth. 

Reference- https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1048636430100170

questions.text:
The value of Va / Q becomes zero when
1. Partial pressure of O2 becomes zero
2. No exchange of O2 & CO2 is taking place
3. Partial pressure of CO2 alone becomes zero
4. Partial pressure of both CO2 and O2 is normal
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: No exchange of O2 & CO2 is taking place V/Q = 0 is seen in airway obstruction V/Q = ∞ is seen in blood flow obstruction The ratio of pulmonary ventilation to pulmonary blood flow for the whole lung at rest is about 0.8. If the ventilation to an alveolus is reduced relative to its perfusion, the PO2 in the alveolus falls because less O2 is delivered to it and the PCO2 rises because less CO2 is expired. Conversely, if perfusion is reduced relative to ventilation, the PCO2 falls because less CO2 is delivered and the PO2 rises because less O2 enters the blood.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 639

questions.text: The JVP waveform is used to assess the status of the right side of the heart and is helpful in diagnosing various cardiovascular conditions. When are C waves in JVP visible?
questions.solution:
When observing the JVP waveform, there are several waves and descents that can be identified: A wave (Atrial contraction): This is the first positive wave seen in the JVP waveform. It corresponds to atrial contraction, which occurs just before ventricular systole (contraction). The A wave reflects the increased pressure caused by blood flowing into the right atrium during atrial contraction. X descent (Atrial relaxation): After the A wave, there is a downward descent known as the X descent. This descent is caused by the relaxation of the right atrium, which results in decreased pressure in the jugular vein. C wave (Isovolumic ventricular contraction): The C wave is a small upward deflection that occurs shortly after the A wave. It represents a slight increase in pressure in the right atrium caused by the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the atrium during isovolumic ventricular contraction. X' descent (Ventricular ejection): Following the C wave, there is a rapid descent known as the X' descent. It is caused by the downward movement of the tricuspid valve as the right ventricle contracts and ejects blood into the pulmonary artery. V wave (Venous filling): The V wave is a large positive wave that occurs after the X' descent. It represents the filling of blood into the right atrium from the peripheral veins during systole. The V wave is often prominent in conditions such as tricuspid regurgitation or right-sided heart failure. Y descent (Rapid ventricular filling): The Y descent is a downward slope that follows the V wave. It represents the rapid ventricular filling phase, during which the tricuspid valve opens and blood flows from the right atrium to the right ventricle.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 530

questions.text: There is a______in hypovolemic shock.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Afferent arteriolar constriction In hypovolemic shock, the body compensates for volume loss by increasing heart rate and contractility, followed by baroreceptor activation resulting in sympathetic nervous system activation and peripheral vasoconstriction. Thus renal blood flow and gfr also decreases. Afferent arteriolar constriction —> decreased gfr —> less fluid loss in urine.This way the blood is shunted towards the heart in c/o shock. Options 2 and 3 are incorrect as efferent arteriolar constriction will result into increased gfr and loss of fluid furthermore. Renal blood flow is decrease and not increased by peripheral vasoconstriction. Option 4 : as effective circulating blood volume is reduced, CO also decreases. Grading of Hypovolemic Shock

 

Reference-:Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 27th Edition Page nos 13,14

choices.text: Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT

questions.text: Except for the following components, all are responsible for the countercurrent mechanism in the kidney:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb

The countercurrent flow of tubular fluid in the loop of Henle and the blood in the vasa recta creates a countercurrent exchange system. This system allows for the reabsorption of water and solutes from the tubular fluid while maintaining the concentration gradient in the renal medulla.
  • Thin Descending Limb: The thin descending limb is highly permeable to water but not to solutes
  • Thin Ascending Limb: At the bottom of the loop of Henle, the thin descending limb transitions into the thin ascending limb. The thin ascending limb is also permeable to water but does not actively transport solutes
  • Thick Ascending Limb: As the thin ascending limb continues to ascend towards the renal cortex, it transitions into the thick ascending limb. The thick ascending limb is impermeable to water but actively transports solutes such as sodium, chloride, and potassium out of the tubule into the interstitial fluid



 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 675,676,677

questions.text: What is serotonin also known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT)
 
  • Serotonin is synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan by a two step process as shown below.

 
  • It is further degraded to 5-OH indole acetic acid.
  • Synthesized in argentaffin cells in intestine, platelets and brain.
  • It functions as neurotransmitter which is responsible for vasoconstriction, mood regulation and gastrointestinal tract motility.
  • Its levels are significantly elevated in neuroendocrine tumors and leads to symptoms such as intermittent diarrhea, cutaneous flushing, sweating and fluctuating hypertension.

questions.text: Which enzyme deficiency results in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT)

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome is an X linked recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase ( HGPRT )
HGPRT is responsible for generation of purine nucleotides such as IMP/GMP from bases such as hypoxanthine/guanine via purine salvage pathway.
As a result, purines accumulate resulting in increased degradation and generation of uric acid leading to hyperuricemia.

Clinically manifests as-
  • Self mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Intellectual disability
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Gout
Remember- Partial deficiency of HGPRTase results in Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 301.

questions.text: Which enzyme deficit is responsible for fish odour syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Monooxygenase 3 (FMO3)

Fish odour syndrome also known as primary trimethylaminuria occours due to the deficiency of Trimethylamine Oxidase (flavin monooxygenase 3 – FMO3).

The gene for FMO3 is located on chr 1q24.3.
 
  • Timethylamine is normally produced in intestine from the breakdown of dietary choline and trimethylamine oxide by bacteria.
  • Trimethylamine is absorbed and oxidised in the liver by trimethylamine oxidase to trimethylamine oxide which is odourless and excreated in urine.
  • Deficiency of this enzyme results in massive excretion of trimethylamine in urine which gives off a fish like body odour.
  • Treatment is done with oral activated charcoal, short courses of oral metronidazole, neomycin or lactulose cause temporary reduction in body odour
  • Restriction of fish, eggs, liver and other sources of choline in the diet is also helpful.


Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3848652/

questions.text: What do chaperones help with?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Protein Folding

Chaperons are a type of heat shock protein which assist in protein folding.
Mechanism of Action
  • Bind to short sequences of hydrophobic amino acids of extended polypeptide.
  • Thereby, they effectively shield the new polypeptide being synthesized from aggregating providing them with an opportunity to form an appropriate secondary structure.
Improper functioning of chaperons results in protein misfolding diseases such as
  • Prion disease: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and bovine spongiform encephalopathy.
  • Alzheimer’s disease
  • Beta thalassemia
Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 444.

questions.text: Which disease is the CD59 marker for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) PNH
 
  • CD59 is a marker for PNH, a rare, acquired disorder characterized by complement-mediated hemolysis due to a deficiency of proteins involved in the protection of red blood cells from complement attack.
* [Extra Edge]: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
 
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a rare, acquired disorder of the blood characterized by the abnormal breakdown of red blood cells (hemolysis) and the presence of dark urine in the morning.
  • It is caused by a mutation in the PIGA gene, leading to a deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins on the surface of blood cells.
  • This results in increased sensitivity to complement-mediated destruction. PNH can lead to anemia, fatigue, and increased susceptibility to infections and blood clots.
  • Diagnosis is made through flow cytometry to detect the absence of GPI-anchored proteins.
  • Treatment options include supportive care, blood transfusions, and targeted therapies such as eculizumab.
Other options:
  • PTEN is a tumor suppressor gene associated with Cowden syndrome, not related to CD59.
  • BRR and Cowden’s syndrome are not associated with CD59.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 648.

questions.text: Bernard-Soulier syndrome results from a lack of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2)Gp 1b
 
  • Bernard-Soulier syndrome (BSS) is a rare bleeding disorder characterized by platelet dysfunction, giant platelets, and prolonged bleeding.
  • It is caused by mutations in the genes encoding the GPIb-IX-V complex, leading to impaired platelet adhesion and aggregation.
  • BSS patients exhibit a higher risk of spontaneous bleeding, easy bruising, and prolonged bleeding after injuries or surgeries.
  • Diagnosis is made through blood tests and examination of giant platelets.
  • Management involves supportive care and treatment of bleeding episodes as needed.
* Other options:
  • Gp 2b/3a is the receptor involved in platelet aggregation, not associated with Bernard-Soulier syndrome. It is involved in Glanzman Thrombesthenia. 
  • vWf (von Willebrand factor) is a protein that plays a role in platelet adhesion, but its deficiency is associated with von Willebrand disease, not Bernard-Soulier syndrome.
  • TNF (Tumor Necrosis Factor) is a cytokine involved in inflammation and is not related to Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

To remember Bernard Soulier and Glansmanz Thrombasthenia, B comes first alphabetically so Gp1 is associated, then comes G so G2b 3a is associated

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 666.

questions.text: How do kidneys react to shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Increases afferent arteriole resistance
 
  • During shock, the kidneys undergo compensatory mechanisms to maintain perfusion.
  • One of the mechanisms is vasoconstriction of the afferent arterioles, which increases resistance and helps maintain blood flow to the vital organs so glomerular filtration rate (GFR) decreases if shock is severe in nature.

*Other options:
  • Decreases renal blood flow would be a consequence of shock rather than a reaction of the kidneys. GFR may decrease as a result of decreased renal blood flow and afferent arteriole vasoconstriction.
  • Decreased perfusion of the kidney is seen in shock.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 135.

questions.text: Pick the most appropriate diagnostic approach for the clinical symptom shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Serum ceruloplasmin.
 
  • Kayser–Fleischer ring is a brownish-yellow area of copper deposition that is present in the peripheral Descemet membrane. 
  • This is seen in Wilson's disease (hepatolenticular degeneration) and occurs due to a deficiency of ceruloplasmin. 
  • Fleischer's rings seen in keratoconus are epithelial iron deposits that are best seen with a cobalt blue filter during slit-lamp examination.
  • Low serum ceruloplasmin level is diagnostic of Wilson's disease.



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3236.

questions.text: Which of the following describes a stomach epithelial tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Gastric adenocarcinoma
 
  • Gastric adenocarcinoma is a malignant epithelial tumor that arises from the glandular cells lining the stomach.
  • Gastric adenocarcinoma is a type of stomach cancer characterized by tumor invasion into the stomach wall, including the deeper layers. It can be classified into different histological types, such as intestinal and diffuse types, based on the appearance of tumor cells.
  • Pathologists also assess the tumor grade, ranging from well-differentiated to poorly differentiated, to determine the aggressiveness of the cancer.
* Other options:
  • Carcinoid tumors arise from neuroendocrine cells and are more commonly found in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Lymphoma refers to malignant tumors of lymphoid tissue and can occur in the stomach but is not specific to epithelial cells. GIST (Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor) is a mesenchymal tumor arising from Interstitial cells of Cajal and is not from epithelial cells.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 774.

questions.text: Determine an X-linked disease.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Color blindness
 
  • Color blindness, or more specifically red-green color blindness, is a well-known X-linked recessive disorder.
  • Color blindness, or color vision deficiency, is a condition characterized by the inability to distinguish certain colors or perceive them accurately.
  • The most common type of color blindness is red-green color blindness, where individuals have difficulty differentiating between shades of red and green.
  • Color blindness is typically caused by inherited genetic mutations that affect the photopigments in the cone cells of the retina.

Other options:
  • Thalassemia is an inherited blood disorder caused by mutations in the globin genes and is not X-linked.
  • Azoospermia refers to the absence of sperm in semen and can have various causes, including genetic factors, but it is not specifically an X-linked disorder.
  • Retinitis Pigmentosa is a group of inherited disorders affecting the retina and can have different inheritance patterns, including X-linked recessive, but it is not the sole X-linked disease.
* [Extra Edge]: Types of inheritance



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 218.

questions.text: One can observe a stellate granuloma in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Cat scratch disease
 
  • Stellate granulomas are a histological finding characterized by a central area of necrosis surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells in a star-shaped pattern.
  • Cat scratch disease, caused by Bartonella henselae, can present with stellate granulomas in lymph nodes.
Option 1 Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas, not stellate granulomas.
Option 3 and 4 Cryptococcosis and histoplasmosis are fungal infections that typically present with granulomas but not specifically stellate granulomas.

* [Extra Edge]: Fungal infection and their characteristics

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the "Flipping effect"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) LDH 1 > LDH 2
 
  • The "Flipping effect" refers to the phenomenon observed in the electrophoresis of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) isoenzymes, where the LDH 1 band becomes more prominent than the LDH 2 band.
  • LDH 1 represents the LDH isoenzyme with the highest electrophoretic mobility, while LDH 2 has lower mobility.
  • In certain conditions, such as myocardial infarction, LDH 1 can increase relative to LDH 2, resulting in the flipping effect.


Online Reference: Weinberger I, Rotenberg Z, Sagie A, Fuchs J, Sperling O, Agmon J. "Flipped" lactic dehydrogenase pattern in acute coronary insufficiency. Clin Cardiol. 1986 Dec;9(12):597-9. doi: 10.1002/clc.4960091202. PMID: 3780075.

questions.text: Xenograft resistance in naked mice is not present due to the lack of
questions.solution:
Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to absence of T cell. A xenograft is a tissue graft or organ transplant form a donor of a different species.

Nude mice lack body hair hence the name. They lack a thymus and thus cannot generate mature T-lymphocytes. The absence of T-lymphocytes makes them unable to mount adaptive immune responses requiring helper T-cells and cytotoxic T-cells. The absence of functioning T-cells also prevents the rejection of allografts and xenografts.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 217.

questions.text: What condition does the picture represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Seminoma

Gross morphology shows pale yellow color enlarged testis with no focal regions of hemorrhage or necrosis.
  • The picture shows a histological image of seminoma, a type of germ cell tumor of the testis.
  • Pathologically, it is characterized by uniform tumor cells with large round or polygonal shape, clear cytoplasm, and central prominent nucleoli.
* Other options:
  • Germ cell differentiate tumor is a broad term that encompasses various types of testicular tumors, including seminoma, embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumor, teratoma, and choriocarcinoma.
  • Non-seminoma refers to testicular tumors that are not pure seminomas, usually comprising a mixture of different germ cell tumor types.
  • Teratoma is a type of germ cell tumor that contains differentiated tissues derived from multiple germ layers.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 970.

choices.text: Changing one type of epithelium to another

questions.text: What is anaplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Lack of differentiation
 
  • Anaplasia refers to the loss of differentiation or dedifferentiation of cells, resulting in a more primitive or undifferentiated appearance.
  • Anaplastic cells typically display features such as pleomorphism, high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, prominent nucleoli, and increased mitotic activity.
*Option 1,2 and 4:
  • Changing one type of epithelium to another refers to metaplasia, not anaplasia.
  • Nuclear chromatin and morphological changes are associated with anaplastic cells but do not fully encompass the concept of anaplasia.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 270.

questions.text: Which prolactin concentration would clearly indicate prolactinoma?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following kidney stones is caused by laxative abuse?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Ammonium urate
 
  • Ammonium urate stones are most likely to be seen in patients with laxative abuse. 
  • Loss of potassium and sodium in laxative abuse causes intracellular acidosis, which increases the production of ammonia in urine. Dehydration and sodium loss further exacerbate hypokalemia and reduces the urinary volume, resulting in hyperuricemia. Highly concentrated uric acid and ammonia promote the formation of ammonium urate stones. 
  • These are also associated with inflammatory bowel disease, chronic diarrhea, ileostomy, recurrent urinary tract infection and recurrent uric acid stone formation. 



Reference: Campbell Walsh Wein Urology, 12th edition, Page no 2032.

questions.text: What condition does the picture represent?

questions.text: What condition does the picture represent?
questions.solution:

  • Miliary tuberculosis appears as numerous small, millet seed-like granulomas in various organs, including the lungs.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent conditions can lead to dactylitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Sickle Cell Anemia

Dactylitis, also known as "sausage digit," refers to painful swelling and inflammation involving an entire finger or toe. It is commonly associated with Sickle cell disease due to irreversible sickling of RBCs leading to Acute painful episodes.

Among the options provided:
  1. Hemophilia: Hemophilia is a bleeding disorder characterized by impaired blood clotting. It does not typically cause dactylitis.
  2. Von Willebrand disease: Von Willebrand disease is another bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor. It is not commonly associated with dactylitis.
  3. Measles: Measles is a viral infection characterized by fever, rash, and respiratory symptoms. It does not typically cause dactylitis.
  • Sickle Cell Anemia: Sickle Cell Anemia is a genetic blood disorder characterized by the presence of abnormal hemoglobin, leading to the formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells.
  • Dactylitis is a well-known manifestation of sickle cell disease and can occur due to vaso-occlusion and infarction in the small blood vessels of the fingers or toes.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 758-760.

questions.text: Who is considered the father of microbiology?
questions.solution:
Louis Pasteur is often referred to as the "Father of Microbiology" due to his groundbreaking contributions to the field. Here are some key points about his work:

Contributions to Microbiology:

  1. Germ Theory of Disease: Pasteur was instrumental in developing the germ theory, which posits that many diseases are caused by microorganisms. This was a revolutionary idea at the time and laid the groundwork for modern medicine.

  2. Pasteurization: He developed the process of pasteurization, which involves heating liquids to kill harmful bacteria. This method is widely used to preserve food and beverages, particularly milk and wine.

  3. Vaccines: Pasteur created vaccines for several diseases, including rabies and anthrax. His work in immunology demonstrated that weakened forms of pathogens could be used to confer immunity.

  4. Fermentation Studies: He conducted extensive research on fermentation, demonstrating that microorganisms were responsible for the process. This work had significant implications for food production and preservation.

  5. Spontaneous Generation: Pasteur's experiments debunked the theory of spontaneous generation, showing that microorganisms came from other microorganisms, not from non-living matter.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 3.

questions.text: What kind of organism is the cause of cutaneous larva migrans?

choices.text: Defect in thick ascending limb of loop of henle

questions.text: Defect is present in Bartter syndrome in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Defect in thick ascending limb of loop of Henle
 
  • Bartter syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by defects in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle in the kidney.
  • The defect in Bartter syndrome leads to impaired reabsorption of sodium, chloride, and potassium, resulting in electrolyte imbalances and a salt-wasting phenotype.
  • This defect is primarily located in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, which plays a critical role in sodium reabsorption.
  • There are different types of Bartter syndrome, each associated with specific genetic mutations affecting various ion channels and transporters in the thick ascending limb.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2293.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis?
questions.solution:
Recurrent pneumonia is NOT seen in ABPA
 
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) is a fungal infection of the lung due to a hypersensitivity reaction to antigens of Aspergillus fumigatus after colonization into the airways.
  • Predominantly it affects patients with bronchial asthma and those having cystic fibrosis.
  • It characteristically presents with bronchospasm, pulmonary infiltrates, eosinophilia, and immunologic evidence of allergy to the antigens of Aspergillus species.
  • It does not cause pneumonia.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2165, 2166.

questions.text: Following waves in ECG are seen in

  • Hyponatremia (low sodium levels) and hypercalcemia (high calcium levels), do not typically cause U waves in an ECG.

questions.text: What is the most typical site for a stomach ulcer?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is lesser curvature.

Gastric ulcers most commonly occur along the lesser curvature of the stomach, particularly near the junction of the body and antrum. This region is more susceptible to mucosal injury due to factors like H. pylori infection, NSAID use, and direct acid exposure.

Other options

  • The pyloric antrum is more commonly associated with duodenal ulcers rather than gastric ulcers.
  • The greater curvature is a less frequent site for ulcers, and when present, it raises concern for malignancy.
  • Ulcers in the large intestine are unrelated to stomach ulcers and are usually caused by inflammatory bowel disease, ischemia, or infections.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 767.

questions.text: The approximate period between contracting HIV and developing AIDS is:

questions.text: What use does Heller's myotomy serve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Achalasia cardia
 
  • Heller's myotomy is a surgical procedure used to treat achalasia cardia, a motility disorder of the esophagus characterized by impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter.
  • During Heller's myotomy, the muscle fibers of the lower esophageal sphincter are cut to relieve the obstruction and improve esophageal emptying.
  1. This involves cutting the muscle of the lower esophagus and gastric cardia.
  2. Typically, anterior myotomy is performed for at least 6 cm proximally at the esophageal side and 2–3 cm distally into the gastric cardia.
  3. Transabdominal or transthoracic approaches have been advocated. Currently, the standard procedure is a laparoscopic approach. The major complication is GORD, which can occur in up to 40% of patients. The addition of a partial fundoplication (anterior Dor or posterior Toupet) has been shown to be effective in reducing the incidence of GORD.
  4. A complete 360° fundoplication (Nissen) is considered contraindicated because the increase in outflow resistance against an a peristaltic esophageal body will probably result in postoperative dysphagia. Laparoscopic myotomy is superior to single pneumatic dilatation in efficacy and durability.
  5. The surgical outcome is better in types I and II achalasia than in type III. For the latter, a longer extended proximal myotomy is often needed for adequate treatment.
* Achalasia cardia:



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1123.

questions.text: The myocardial stunning pattern does not correspond to the ECG. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as "broken heart syndrome" or "stress-induced cardiomyopathy," is a condition characterized by a sudden weakening of the heart muscle. It often occurs following a stressful or emotional event.
 
  • One of the distinguishing features of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is that the pattern of myocardial stunning or dysfunction does not correspond to the typical distribution of coronary arteries, meaning that the area of myocardial dysfunction is not directly related to a specific blockage or ischemia in the coronary arteries.
 
  • On the other hand, restrictive cardiomyopathy (option 2) is characterized by impaired filling of the ventricles due to stiffness or fibrosis of the heart muscle, and it is not typically associated with myocardial stunning.
 
  • Brugada cardiomyopathy (option 3) refers to Brugada syndrome, an inherited arrhythmia disorder that primarily affects the electrical conduction system of the heart, causing abnormal ECG patterns and an increased risk of life-threatening arrhythmias. It is not directly associated with myocardial stunning. ECG pattern if Brugada syndrome is is known as the "Brugada pattern" or "Brugada sign." It is typically observed in the right precordial leads (V1 to V3) most commonly as ST elevation.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1966.

questions.text: An alternative drug to epinephrine for treating cardiac arrest is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Amiodarone. Amiodarone is an alternative drug that can be used in the treatment of cardiac arrest.

It is administered during advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) as a substitute for or in combination with epinephrine. It can be particularly useful in certain situations, such as VF or pVT, where the effectiveness of epinephrine may be limited.

Apart from Epinephrine, Amiodarone and Lignocaine are other two drugs recommended by AHA for the treatment of Adult Cardiac arrest. Rest other drugs are NOT recommended.

ACLS algorithm:
  • Step 1: Assess responsiveness Determine if the patient is responsive and shout for help.
  • Step 2: Activate emergency response system Activate the emergency response system or ask someone to do it.
  • Step 3: Check for a pulse Assess for the presence of a pulse. If absent or not palpable within 10 seconds, proceed to the next step.
  • Step 4: Start high-quality CPR Begin high-quality CPR with a compression-to-ventilation ratio of 30:2 for adult patients. Ensure adequate depth and rate of compressions with minimal interruptions.
  • Step 5: Attach and analyze a defibrillator Attach an automated external defibrillator (AED) or manual defibrillator to the patient and analyze the rhythm.
  • Step 6: Deliver defibrillation If a shockable rhythm (ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia) is detected, deliver a single shock and immediately resume CPR.
  • Step 7: Perform rhythm checks After 2 minutes of CPR, assess the rhythm to determine if it is shockable or non-shockable.
  • Step 8: Administer medications Administer medications as indicated based on the rhythm and protocol. Epinephrine is typically given every 3-5 minutes. Additionally, consider administering vasopressin as an alternative vasopressor to one dose of epinephrine.
  • Step 9: Continue cycles of CPR and rhythm assessments Perform cycles of CPR with rhythm checks every 2 minutes. Follow the specific guidelines for rhythm interpretation, shock delivery, and medication administration.
  • Step 10: Consider advanced airway management If feasible and in accordance with local protocols, consider advanced airway management such as endotracheal intubation or supraglottic airway placement.
  • Step 11: Post-resuscitation care After return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC), provide post-resuscitation care, including monitoring, optimizing oxygenation and ventilation, treating underlying causes, and transferring the patient to an appropriate care setting.





Reference: Adult Cardiac Arrest algorithm, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 guidelines. URL: https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms

questions.text:
Which investigation should be carried out next to assist you diagnose the ailment if the patient has cutaneous vasculitis,
glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: ANCA
 
  • ANCA testing (option 1) is the most relevant investigation for the presented clinical scenario.
  • RA factor (option 2) is associated with rheumatoid arthritis and is not specific to the described symptoms.
  • HbsAg (option 3) is a marker for hepatitis B infection and is not directly related to the presented symptoms.
  • MIF (option 4) stands for Macrophage Migration Inhibitory Factor, which is not a specific test for the mentioned symptoms.

ANCA testing is commonly used in the evaluation of vasculitis, specifically in distinguishing between different types of vasculitis. ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV) is a group of autoimmune disorders that includes granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), microscopic polyangiitis (MPA), and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). ANCA testing helps in detecting the presence of specific autoantibodies that target neutrophil components and are associated with these types of vasculitis.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2803, 2804.

questions.text: Cryoglobulinemia is associated with which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hepatitis C
 
  • Cryoglobulinemia is a condition characterized by the presence of abnormal proteins called cryoglobulins in the blood. These proteins can precipitate and cause inflammation and damage in blood vessels, leading to various symptoms and complications.
  • The most common type of cryoglobulinemia, known as type II or mixed cryoglobulinemia, is strongly associated with chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection.
  • It is estimated that approximately 80-90% of cases of mixed cryoglobulinemia are associated with HCV.
  • Ovarian cancer, diabetes, and leukemia are not typically associated with cryoglobulinemia. While cryoglobulinemia can be secondary to other underlying conditions or diseases, HCV infection is the most common and well-established association.

Some common extra-articular manifestations associated with Hepatitis C infection:






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2604.

questions.text: What is the causes of hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Liddle syndrome

The other options are incorrect because:
  1. Bartter syndrome: Bartter syndrome is characterized by excessive renal sodium and chloride excretion, leading to volume depletion, potassium wasting, metabolic alkalosis, and secondary hyperaldosteronism. However, Bartter syndrome is not typically associated with hypertension.
  2. Gitelman syndrome: Gitelman syndrome also involves excessive renal excretion of sodium and chloride, resulting in volume depletion, potassium wasting, metabolic alkalosis, and secondary hyperaldosteronism. However, Gitelman syndrome is not commonly associated with hypertension.
  3. Renal tubular acidosis (RTA): While some forms of RTA can cause hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, they are not typically associated with hypertension. RTA involves impaired renal tubular acidification, leading to an inability to excrete acid and maintain normal acid-base balance.







Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 349, 350.

  • Minimal Dysfunction Syndrome/ Minimal Brain Dysfunction is the old term used to describe a condition which is now popularly known as  (ADHD).
  • The hypothesis that minimal brain damage may lead to behavior disorders became well established. In the 1960s, however, many critics emerged who criticized the tests commonly used in the assessment of brain damage and challenged the argument that every child presenting with abnormal behavior was to have minimal brain damage

 
Reference: Lange, Klaus W et al. “The history of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.” Attention deficit and hyperactivity disorders vol. 2,4 (2010): 241-55. doi:10.1007/s12402-010-0045-8.

questions.text: Amphotericin B acts at the following sites:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Plasma membrane
 
  • Amphotericin B acts on ergosterol present in cell membrane. Answer is Cell/plasma membrane.
  • Cholesterol, present in host cell membranes, closely resembles ergosterol; the polyenes bind to cholesterol as well, though with lesser affinity.
  • Thus, the selectivity of action of polyenes is low, and AMB is one of the most toxic systemically used antibiotics, though it is the least toxic polyene. Bacteria do not have sterols and are unaffected by polyenes.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 839.

questions.text: Which antiviral(HIV) medication also has hepatitis-fighting properties?

questions.text: Which drug is best for resistant rheumatic chorea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Valproate
 
  • Intractable Sydenham's Chorea is a neurological disorder characterized by involuntary movements.
  • It is typically associated with rheumatic fever. When symptoms are severe and do not respond to other treatments, Valproate is recommended.
  • Valproate is an antiepileptic medication, works by increasing the levels of GABA, a neurotransmitter that helps regulate neuronal activity.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2768.

questions.text: What is the replacement dose of hydrocortisone (mg/day) for Chronic Adrenal Insufficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 4. 20 mg/day.
 
  • Glucocorticoid replacement for the treatment of chronic adrenal insufficiency should be administered at a dose that replaces the physiologic daily cortisol production, which is usually achieved by the oral administration of 15–25 mg hydrocortisone in two to three divided doses.
 
  • Pregnancy may require an increase in hydrocortisone dose by 50% during the last trimester. In all patients, at least one-half of the daily dose should be administered in the morning. 

Therefore, among the given options 20 mg/day will be the most appropriate answer.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2972.

questions.text: What is colchicine's mode of action in acute gout?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Leukocytes, lymphocytes inhibition & microtubular inhibitor.
 
  • Colchicine works to treat acute gout by inhibiting neutrophilic migration, which is the movement of white blood cells (neutrophils) to the site of inflammation caused by the accumulation of uric acid crystals in the joint. This inhibition reduces the inflammatory response in the affected area and thus helps to alleviate pain, swelling, and tenderness. 
  • It binds to tubulin and inhibits microtubule polymerization thereby impairing neutrophil chemotaxis and degranulation.
  • Colchicine does not inhibit urate oxidase, xanthine oxidase, or cyclooxygenase, which are enzymes involved in the production of uric acid or inflammation. Allopurinol inhibits Xanthine oxidase while NSAIDs inhibit cyclooxygenase.
  • Colchicine is considered a second-line treatment for acute gout, used when nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or corticosteroids are ineffective, contraindicated, or not tolerated.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 231.

questions.text: What is Basiliximab?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: IL-2 receptor antagonist

Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody that binds specifically to the alpha chain of the IL-2 receptor (CD25) on activated T lymphocytes. By blocking the IL-2 receptor, basiliximab inhibits IL-2 signaling and T-cell activation, which is crucial in the immune response. It is commonly used as an immunosuppressive agent in organ transplantation to prevent acute rejection.

The other options are incorrect:
  1. IL-1 receptor antagonist (anakinra) is a different medication used to block IL-1 signaling and is used in the treatment of certain inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis.
  2. Anti-CD3 antibody (muromonab-CD3) is a different medication that targets CD3 antigen on T cells and has been used in the past for immunosuppression in transplant and autoimmune diseases.
  3. TNF inhibitors are a class of medications that specifically target tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha), a pro-inflammatory cytokine involved in various autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, and inflammatory bowel disease. Examples of TNF inhibitors include drugs like adalimumab and infliximab.
Memorizing trick- 
Basiliximab- B is the 2nd letter of English alphabet hence IL-2 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 943.

questions.text: Which antipsychotic on the list below causes increased prolactin secretion?
questions.solution:

  • It has combined D2 + 5-HT2 receptor blocking property. In addition, it has high affinity for α1, α2 and H1 receptors: blockade of these may contribute to efficacy as well as side effects like postural hypotension. However, BP can rise if it is given with a SSRI.
  • Risperidone is more potent D2 blocker than clozapine; extrapyramidal side effects are less only at low doses (<6 mg/day). Prolactin levels rise disproportionately during Risperidone therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Prasugrel is false?

Prasugrel is a prodrug that is converted to an active metabolite by the hepatic CYP system It is a ADP P2Y12 receptor blocker It is an antiplatelet drug which decreases platelet aggregation

USE :- Prasugrel is used in combination with low dose aspirin to prevent thrombosis in patients with acute coronary syndrome including unstable angina, non ST elevation MI, ST elevation MI who are planned for treatment with PCI.
Prasugrel is associated with a higher bleeding risk, hence should not be given to people with active pathological bleeding such as peptic ulcer or a history of transient ischemic attack or stroke. It is associated with higher risk of stroke (thrombotic stroke and intracranial hemorrhage).

questions.text: Which medication exhibits Q-T Prolongation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Quinidine
 
  • Quinidine blocks Na+ current and multiple cardiac K+ currents. It is an open-state blocker of Na+ channels, with a τ recovery in the intermediate range. Thus, after therapeutic dosages, QRS duration increases modestly, usually by 10% to 20%.
  • At therapeutic concentrations, quinidine commonly prolongs the QT interval up to 25%, but the effect is highly variable.
  • Drugs causing QTc prolongation - 
  • Category Drugs
    Antiarrhythmics (Class 1a & 3) Quinidine, Procainamide, Disopyramide, Amiodarone, Sotalol, Dofetilide, Ibutilide
    Antibiotics Erythromycin, Clarithromycin, Levofloxacin, Ciprofloxacin, Moxifloxacin
    Antifungals Fluconazole, Itraconazole, Voriconazole
    Antipsychotics Haloperidol, Quetiapine, Risperidone, Olanzapine, Ziprasidone
    Antidepressants Amitriptyline, Imipramine, Citalopram, Escitalopram
    Antiemetics Ondansetron, Granisetron, Domperidone
    Other Drugs Methadone, Chloroquine, Hydroxychloroquine, Lithium, Tacrolimus
Other options: -
2. Amiodarone- class 3 antiarrythmic drug blocks potassium channel, causes QT prolongation but lesser than quinidine.
3. Magnesium sulfate is used in treatment of Torsa des depointes
4. Lignocaine - class 1b antiarryhmic drug doesn't cause QT prolongation 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 572.

questions.text: What exactly is Sacubitril?

  • Use: - Used in combination with Valsartan to treat Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction
  • Adverse effects: - Hypotension, Cough (Due to increase in levels of Bradykinin)
  • Contraindications: - It is contraindicated with ACE inhibitors since both drugs increase the level of Bradykinin
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 553.

questions.text: Which antibiotic is not bacteriostatic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Vancomycin

*Mechanism of Action:
  • Vancomycin acts by inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis.
  • It binds to the terminal dipeptide ‘D-ala-D-ala’ sequence of peptidoglycan units—prevents its release from the bactoprenol lipid carrier so that assembly of the units at the cell membrane and their cross linking to form the cell wall cannot take place.
Other options: -
  • Tetracyclines and Clindamycin are protein synthesis inhibitors hence are bacteriostatic
  • Cephalosporins also act as bactericidal, but Vancomycin is a better answer

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 741.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions results in melanosis coli?

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics will be prescribed to a bedridden patient with pneumonia and a catheter-related UTI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Beta Lactam antibiotics with beta lactamase

Beta lactam antibiotics with beta lactamase antibiotic will have greater coverage and will be effective in beta lactamase producing organisms.
They are mostly involved in bedridden patient with pneumonia and a catheter-related UTI.

Beta-lactamase-producing organisms are bacteria that produce an enzyme called beta-lactamase. This enzyme can break down and destroy commonly used antibiotics such as penicillin and cephalosporins, making them ineffective in treatment. Examples of such organisms include:
  • Gram-positive organisms (such as Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus epidermidis).
  • Gram-negative organisms (such as Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Moraxella catarrhalis, Escherichia coli, and Proteus, Serratia, Pseudomonas, and Klebsiella species).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 747.

questions.text: What is Mycoplasma resistant to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ceftriaxone
 
  • Like all microorganisms that lack cell wall, M. pneumoniae is intrinsically resistant to beta-lactams and to all antimicrobials targeting the cell wall, such as glycopeptides and Fosfomycin.  Ceftriaxone is a 3rd generation cephalosporin and hence, a beta lactam and mycoplasma would be resitant to ceftriazxone. 
  • M. pneumoniae is also resistant to polymixins, sulfonamides, trimethoprim, rifampicin and linezolid.
  • Antibiotics with potential activity against M. pneumoniae that are used in clinical practice include macrolides, lincosamides, streptogramin combinations and ketolides (MLSK), tetracyclines and fluoroquinolones.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 778.

questions.text: You shouldn't take tadalafil with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Vasodilator
 
  • Tadalafil markedly potentiates the vasodilator action of nitrates and precipitous fall in BP, MI can occur.
  • Tadalafil is contraindicated in patients of coronary heart disease and those taking nitrates. Though sildenafil remains effective for <8 hours, it is advised that nitrates be avoided for 24 hours.
  • Tadalafil is an example of PDE5 inhibitor. Inhibition of Phosphodiesterase leads to increased levels of cGMP. Drugs like Tadalafil, Sildenafil thus leads to vasodilation, flushing, smooth muscle relaxation, tachycardia.
  • Hence Tadalafil should not be combined with other vasodilator drugs.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 328.

questions.text: How much ringer lactate could a 50 kg male with 2° burns expect to use in the first 8 hours with 40% burns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option (3) -  2 litres

Ringer's lactate is the most commonly used crystalloid in burns as it most closely replicates the osmolality of plasma.

Fluid resuscitation is done as per the modified Parkland formula. 
Fluid required in 24 hours = 2ml/kg X TBSA(%)   (Body surface area involved in burn)
Note: 50% of calculated fluid is given over 8 hours, remaining 50% over 16 hours.

Inputing these values for the above scenario - 2ml/kg X 50kg X 40 = 4000ml (4L) in 24 hours. Therefore, 50% of 4L - i.e. 2L needs to be given in the first 8 hours. Hence, the correct option is Option (3) -  2 liters

Remember, Fluid requirement is different in
A.Children (<14y) =  [3ml/kg X Wt(kg)X TBSA(%)]
B.Electrical burns = [4ml/kg X Wt(kg)X TBSA %]



Reference: ATLS (Advanced trauma life support) 10th edition page 174

questions.text: Which provision of the IPC does the M'Naughten Rule fall under?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: IPC 84
 
  • McNaughten's rule falls under IPC 84. Mc Naughten’s rule also known as the McNaughten test or the right-wrong test, is a legal standard used in some jurisdictions to determine the criminal responsibility of individuals with mental disorders.
  • The rule focuses on the cognitive aspect of the defendant's mental state. It states that a defendant is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, they were suffering from a mental disorder that affected their ability to understand the nature and quality of the act.
  • The burden of proof rests on the defendant, who must establish the defense of insanity.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 493.

questions.text: What is Locard known for?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Theory of Exchange 'Locard's Exchange Principle' 

When any two objects come into contact, there is always a transfer of material from each object on the other. Trace from the scene may be carried away on the person or tool of the criminal, and at the same time, traces from all or any of these may be left at the scene.

It is actual evidence, and its presence is absolute proof of the crime. The evidence of eyewitnesses may be wrong as a result of their partisanship, faulty memory, or defective observation. Physical evidence cannot be wrong and completely absent. Only its interpretation can be wrong. Only human failure to find it, study and understand it, can diminish its value.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 443.

questions.text: Which of the following constitutional provisions has nothing to do with children?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: 42

Article 42 stands for just and humane working conditions and maternity relief. It states “The State shall make provision for securing humane conditions of work and for maternity relief”. It has nothing to do with children.

Option 1: Article 23 states “Traffic in human beings and beggar and other similar forms of forced labor are prohibited and any contravention of this provision shall be an offence punishable in accordance with law.” Children are also included in the term ‘human beings’

Option 2: Article 21-A states that the State shall provide free and compulsory education to all children of the age of six to fourteen years in such manner as the State may, by law, determine.

Option 4: Article 24 says that “No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment.”

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 23.

questions.text:
A disease has a 4 per 1000 population incidence rate and a 2-year duration.
Determine the prevalence?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 8/1000

Prevalence is the proportion of cases, all old and new at a given point or for a period of time within a defined population.

Prevalence depends on incidence and duration.
The formula is:
Prevalence = Incidence x Mean duration
P = 4/1000 x 2 = 8/1000 Ans.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 69.

questions.text: Which strategy is used to dispose of cytotoxic and outdated medications?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Landfill.
  • Cytotoxic medications and outdated drugs are considered hazardous pharmaceutical waste.
  • The preferred method for disposing of such waste is through landfill disposal in specifically designated hazardous waste disposal sites.
  • Proper disposal of pharmaceutical waste is crucial to prevent environmental contamination and potential harm to human health.
  • Dumping is not an acceptable method of disposing of hazardous waste.
  • Autoclaving and burning are effective methods of destroying cytotoxic and outdated medications, but they are not practical for large quantities of waste.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 917.

questions.text: What procedure is used for disposing of cytotoxic and outdated medications?

  • Addition of sawdust, paper, kerosene or other combustible material aid in burning.
  • Faeces can be disposed off by burning.
  • Burning should not be done in open air; it is best done in an incinerator.
 Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 140.

questions.text: The study unit for ecological research is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Population

The unit of ecological study designs is population.
Ecological study includes correlation between variables. A third party source of information is taken. E.g. Alcohol consumption in a state is estimated from alcohol tax data.

Epidemiological studies can be classified as observational studies and experimental studies with further subdivisions 

1. Observational studies

a. Descriptive studies   
b. Analytical studies
(i) Ecological or Correlational, with populations as unit of study
(ii) Cross-sectional or Prevalence, with individuals as unit of study
(iii) Case-control or + Case-reference,  with individuals as unit of study
{iv) Cohort or Follow-up, with individuals as unit of study

2. Experimental studies or Intervention studies

a. Randomized or  Clinical trials with patients as controlled trials trials unit of study
b, Field trials with healthy people as unit of study
c. Community trials or Community intervention trial with communities as unit of study.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 70.

questions.text: 90 people in a population of 1000 tested positive for DM during a screening. Then, 100 out of 100 gold standard tests were positive. Do the sensitivity calculations.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 90/100

According to the question,
90 people out of 1000 tested positive
100 out of 100 gold standard tests were positive.

Therefore,
Test positive and Disease positive = 90 ( TRUE POSITIVE )
Test negative but Disease positive = 100-90= 10 ( FALSE NEGATIVE )

Sensitivity =TRUE POSITIVE/(TRUE POSITIVE +FALSE NEGATIVE) 
                  = 90/100


Hence, Sensitivity = 90/100.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 155.

questions.text: How is meningococcal meningitis being treated by mass chemoprophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Rifampicin

The following drugs are used for mass chemoprophylaxis in Meningococcal meningitis :-
  • Rifampicin
  • Ceftriaxone
  • Ciprofloxacin
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 184.

questions.text: Which of the aforementioned is a form of chlorination that is active?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Hypochlorous acid.
 
  • Chlorination is a common method used to disinfect water and eliminate harmful microorganisms.
  • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
    • HOCl → H + OCl
  • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
  • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 841.

questions.text: Except for________, Kala-Azar is present in all endemic regions.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Assam

Kala azar is endemic in 53 districts in Bihar, Jharkhand, West Bengal, and UP.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 352.

questions.text: The definition of risk among exposed by risk among non exposed is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Relative risk

 
  • Relative risk or risk ratio is the incidence of disease among exposed to incidence among non-exposed.
  • It is calculated with the help of cohort study.
  • RR = I (exposed) / I (non-exposed)
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 81.

questions.text: When is pasteurisation carried out?
questions.solution:
Correct option is B: 63°C For 30 min.
 
  • Pasteurization is the process of applying heat, to milk, for a specified period for the purpose of killing pathogenic bacteria. There are two methods:
  1. holder method and
  2. flash method.
  • It requires temperatures of about 63 °C (145 °F) maintained for 30 minutes or, alternatively, heating to a higher temperature, 72 °C (162 °F), and holding for 15 seconds (and yet higher temperatures for shorter periods of time).


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 144.

questions.text: Ideally, two live vaccinations should be spaced out by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: 4 weeks
  • Ideally, two different live vaccines should be given 4 weeks apart.
  • This prevents interference of the first vaccine with the second one.
NOTE:
  1. Two doses of the same vaccine are also the most effective if given in a 4 week apart duration.
  2. It ensures optimal immune response.
  3. Decreasing the interval between doses in a multiple-dose vaccine series may interfere with antibody response and protection.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 111.

questions.text:
Susceptible person developed disease within range of IP after coming in
contact with primary case -
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Secondary attack rate

Secondary attack rate is defined as the number of secondary cases which arise within one incubation period of the first case among susceptible people/close contacts.

SAR = Total no. of secondary cases in an area /          * 100
           (Total susceptible population – primary case)

The denominator consists of all persons who are exposed to the case. More specifically, the denominator may be restricted only to “susceptible” contacts, if means are available to distinguish the susceptible persons from the immune .
The primary case is excluded from both the numerator and denominator.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 108.

questions.text:
After being monitored for 24 months, 10 of the 100 women who were offered ocp for contraception became pregnant.
What is the index of Pearl?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: 5
 
  • Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY). Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure
  • In the given scenario, the pearl index is 5 per HWY.
  • Here, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 10. There are 100 couples who are exposed to the method.
  • So, the total months of exposure are 24 months x 100 = 2400.
Hence, pearl index = 10 x 1200/2400 = 5 per HWY.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 585.

questions.text: Which of the following does not contribute to water hardness?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Calcium carbonate. Calcium carbonate does not cause hardness of water. Hardness of water is caused by bicarbonates and sulphates of calcium and magnesium. 
  • Water hardness is determined by the concentration of calcium and magnesium ions in water.


There are two types of hardness of water:

questions.text: Which of the following infectious illness examples does not involve direct transmission?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Respiratory
Among the given options, respiratory infections is the most appropriate answer to this question.
This is because respiratory infections can occur both by Direct Mode ( via Droplet infection ) or by Indirect Mode (Air borne – Droplet nuclei).

Direct means of transmission are: -
  • Fomite
  • droplet
  • soil 
  • Sexual contact
  • Blood 
  • Transplacental 


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 105.

questions.text: The water's view is used to get diagnostic data on:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Maxillary sinus
 
  • The Waters' view is a radiographic view of the skull that is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.
  • During the Water's view X-ray, the patient's head is positioned with the forehead and nose against the X-ray film or detector.
  • An x-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line.
  • The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

  




Reference:P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery 8th Edition Page no 509

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Foreign body obstructing airway Foreign body obstructing the airway requires an urgent Tracheostomy. Other indications of tracheostomy include- Prolonged mechanical ventilation Prevention of aspiration in case of bilateral vocal cord palsy Obstruction above tracheal rings 2,3,4 either by infection, tumor or trauma.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 360

questions.text: Which thickened nerve is visible in the picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Great auricular nerve
 
  • The great auricular nerve is a cutaneous nerve that supplies sensation to the skin of the ear and the side of the neck. It is a branch of the cervical plexus.
  • The great auricular nerve is often thickened in people with leprosy, a chronic infectious disease that affects the skin, nerves, and limbs.
  • The facial nerve, vagus nerve, and glossopharyngeal nerve are all cranial nerves that supply the head and neck. They are not visible in the picture.
  • The picture shows a person with probably leprosy, and the thickened nerve is the great auricular nerve.
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 554.e1,573

questions.text: What is the purpose of Caldwell's view?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Frontal sinus
 
  • The Caldwell view is primarily used to assess the frontal sinuses
  • It can also be used to assess the ethmoidal sinuses and the superior portion of the maxillary sinuses. However, it is not as effective for visualizing the maxillary sinuses as the Waters' view.
  • During the Caldwell's view X-ray, the patient's head is positioned with the chin raised, and the X-ray beam is directed through the patient's skull from below the face.
  • Caldwell's view is particularly useful in assessing the frontal sinuses for any abnormalities or signs of sinusitis, sinus infections, or other sinus-related conditions
  


 

Reference:P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery 8th Edition Page no 509

questions.text: Presbyopic correction in a 55-year-old patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. +2D

The treatment of Presbyopia is the prescription of appropriate convex glasses for near work.

Rough guide for providing presbyopic glasses in an emmetrope can be made from the age of the patient:
  • 45 years: +1 to +1.25D
  • 50 years: +1.25 to +1.75D
  • 55 years: +2 to +2.25D
  • 60 years: +2.5 to +3D
Assuming age to be 55 years, +2 is the prescribed correction as we should never over-correct Presbyopia.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 48.

questions.text: An 60 year aged person's presbyopic correction power would be:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. +3D

The treatment of Presbyopia is the prescription of appropriate convex glasses for near work.

Rough guide for providing presbyopic glasses in an emmetrope can be made from the age of the patient:
  • 45 years: +1 to +1.25D
  • 50 years: +1.25 to +1.75D
  • 55 years: +2 to +2.25D
  • 60 years: +2.5 to +3D
Assuming age to be 60 years, +3D is the prescribed correction as we should never over-correct Presbyopia.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 48.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with 100-day glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO)
 
  • 100-day glaucoma is a neovascular glaucoma that occurs in ischemic type of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). It is known as 100-day glaucoma because it occurs 3 months after the episode of CRVO. Up to 50% of eyes develop NVG following ischemic CRVO.
  • Fundus examination shows massive enlargement of retinal veins and massive retinal hemorrhages giving a "splashed tomato appearance". Other findings include cotton wool spots, optic disc edema and neovascularization at the disc and in the periphery.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 529.

questions.text: Roth spots can be found in:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Acute leukemia. Roth's spots are seen in acute leukemia.
 
  • Roth's spots are retinal hemorrhages with white or pale center. In Roth's spot the white center due to coagulated fibrin-platelet plug is surrounded by red rim that is caused by hemorrhage. They are typically associated with certain medical conditions.
  • Roth's spots may be seen in: Leukemia, Diabetes, Subacute bacterial endocarditis (SABE), Sickle cell retinopathy, Hypertensive retinopathy, HIV retinopathy, Systemic lupus erythematosus etc.
  • Patients with leukemia can present with retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, Roth spots, retinal microaneurysms, or neovascularization



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 793.

questions.text: The right lateral rectus has the following yoke muscle:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Lt medial rectus.
 
  • The concept of yoke muscles in ocular movements refers to the pairs of muscles that work together to move the eyes in a coordinated manner.
  • Rotation of both eyes in the same direction is termed version. During version, the muscles of both eyes make an equal effort to rotate them to the same gaze angles (Hering’s law). These paired agonists are called yoke muscles.
  • The lateral rectus muscle is responsible for abduction, which is the outward movement of the eye.
  • Its yoke muscle, the one that works in conjunction with it, is the medial rectus muscle of the opposite eye. 
  • The medial rectus muscle is responsible for adduction, which is the inward movement of the eye.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1194.

questions.text: What causes severe conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Neisseria.
 
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a bacterium that can cause severe conjunctivitis known as gonococcal conjunctivitis/ hyperacute conjunctivitis.
  • It is typically transmitted through sexual contact or from an infected mother to her newborn during delivery.
  • Gonococcal conjunctivitis can result in marked redness, discharge, and swelling of the conjunctiva.
  • Untreated cases may lead to peripheral corneal ulceration and eventual perforation with possible endophthalmitis. Thus, it can cause potential vision loss.
  • Staphylococcus, Streptococcus and Haemophilus cause milder forms of self limiting acute conjunctivitis. 




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 183.

questions.text: Which of the following prescription is an example of Simple Myopic Astigmatism?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. -1 DC X 180 degree
 
  • Among the options provided, the correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC x 180 degrees. In SMA, one principal meridian is focused on the retina, while the other is positioned in front of it.
  • The prescription for glasses in cases of astigmatism includes three components: 
1. Power of the spherical component—either convex (+) or concave (-) diopter sphere (DS).
2. Power of the cylinder—either convex (+) or concave (-) diopter cylinder (DC).
3. Axis (orientation) of the cylinder.
 
  • For instance, in the prescription -1.00 DC x 180 degrees, there is no spherical component (or it is plano), meaning one meridian focuses on the retina, indicating simple astigmatism. The -1.00 DC signifies that a concave cylinder is employed to focus the myopic rays from the other meridian, with the cylinder axis oriented at 180 degrees.


Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 48.

questions.text: An orbital blowout fracture includes:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Floor.
 
  • Blow-out orbital fractures are caused by trauma to the orbit by a large, rounded object, e.g., cricket ball, a human fist, etc. 
  • This force can cause the displacement of the eyeball backward and an increase in intra-orbital pressure. 
  • This leads to fracturing at the weakest point of the orbital wall (orbital floor and sometimes medial wall).  

Image shows Orbital blow out fracture 



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 440-442.
Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page no 894-897.

questions.text: What kind of retractor is depicted in the picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Morris retractor
  • The retractor depicted in the picture is a Morris retractor.

Czerny retractor

Richardson retractor
