questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the image's suture material is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Degraded by enzymatic degradation
 
  • Catgut suture undergoes enzymatic degradation by proteolytic enzymes present in the body, allowing for gradual absorption and breakdown of the suture material over time.
  • This degradation process is important for minimizing tissue reaction and promoting wound healing.
  • Catgut is made from sheep submucosa .
  • Frequent Use of Catgut is: To Ligate superficial vessels, suture subcutaneous tissues. Stomas and other tissues that heal rapidly.
* [Extra Edge]:



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 106.

questions.text: The Van Nuys Prognostic Index does not depend on:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) ER status
 
  • The Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is a scoring system used to assess the prognosis of patients with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of the breast.
  • The VNPI takes into account several factors, including age, tumor size, nuclear grade, and presence of comedo necrosis.
  • ER status (estrogen receptor status) is not included in the VNPI and, therefore, does not impact the calculation of the index.
  • The VNPI is based on Micro SWAG i.e, microcalcification, size of lesion, width of surgical margin, age of the patient and DCIS Nuclear grade.


Fig: Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI)

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 844.

questions.text: Most common cause of chronic pancreatitis is:
questions.solution:
Chronic alcohol abuse is a major risk factor for developing chronic pancreatitis. Prolonged alcohol intake leads to pancreatic injury and inflammation, eventually resulting in the development of chronic pancreatitis.
 
  • Other causes of chronic pancreatitis include long-standing pancreatic calculi (option 2) that obstruct the pancreatic duct, pancreatic divisum (option 3), a congenital anatomical variation of the pancreatic ducts, and gallbladder stones (option 4), which can cause recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis but are less commonly associated with chronic pancreatitis.
 
  • A common mnemonic used to remember the causes of chronic pancreatitis is
  • TIGAR-O: Toxic-metabolic, Idiopathic, Genetic, Autoimmune, Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis and Obstructive
Most common cause of Acute pancreatitis is GB stone. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2665.

choices.text: Extended excision is the treatment of choice
It do not extend beyond the wound

questions.text: Regarding Keloid, the following statement is accurate:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) It contain growth factor
 
  • Keloid is an abnormal overgrowth of scar tissue that forms at the site of a wound or injury.
  • It is characterized by excessive collagen deposition and an imbalance in collagen synthesis and degradation.
  • One accurate statement about keloids is that they contain growth factors. These growth factors, such as transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta), platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF), and fibroblast growth factor (FGF), play a crucial role in promoting the growth and persistence of keloid scars.
  • The overexpression of these growth factors leads to abnormal fibroblast proliferation and collagen synthesis, contributing to the raised and hypertrophic appearance of keloids. Location of keloid commonly found on chest, shoulders and earlobes. Location of hypertrophic scar can occur anywhere on the body.
  • Excision can lead to recurrence of keloid. Intralesional Triamcinolone is the treatment of choice. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 110.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent layers undergoes a fasciotomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Skin+subcutaneous tissue+Superficial fascia+deep fascia
 
  • Fasciotomy is a surgical procedure performed to relieve compartment syndrome, a condition characterized by increased pressure within a closed muscle compartment.
  • During a fasciotomy, all subsequent layers, including the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and deep fascia, are incised to release the pressure within the compartment and restore blood flow to the tissues.
* [Extra Edge]: 
 
  • Acute compartment syndrome occurs when there is increased interstitial pressure within a closed osteofascial compartment, which results in microvascular compromise.
  • It is a surgical emergency as delayed treatment may lead to irreversible muscle ischemia and significant long-term morbidity.
  • Compartment syndrome is generally a clinical diagnosis. It can be difficult to diagnose in the presence of impaired consciousness, in children and in patients with regional nerve blocks.
  • Monitoring intra compartment pressures (ICPs) can sometimes help to guide management. A pressure of ≤30 mmHg between the diastolic pressure and ICP has been recommended as the threshold for fasciotomy.
  • Fasciotomy involves incising the skin and deep fascia with long axial incisions. If the compartment pressure was high, the muscle will then be seen bulging out through the fasciotomy opening. The lower limb is reliably decompressed via two incisions. A medial longitudinal incision 1–2 cm posterior to the medial border of the tibia decompresses the superficial and deep posterior compartments. A lateral longitudinal incision 2 cm lateral to the anterior tibial border decompresses the peroneal and anterior compartments.

  • Late diagnosis of compartment syndrome is a management dilemma as a late fasciotomy may result in rhabdomyolysis, infection, need for amputation and even death.


    Fig: Fasciotomy of the leg

    Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 33.

questions.text: Which of the following about Crohn's disease is untrue
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Continuous lesion visualized in endoscopy
 
  • The untrue statement is 2. Continuous lesion visualized in endoscopy.
  • Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the digestive tract, from the mouth to the anus.
  • While Crohn's disease most commonly involves the terminal ileum (the last part of the small intestine) and the colon, it can also affect the rectum. Crohn's disease can affect different segments of the gastrointestinal tract in a patchy manner, with skip lesions.
  • Involvement of the rectum in Crohn's disease can lead to symptoms such as rectal bleeding, mucous discharge, tenesmus (the feeling of incomplete evacuation), and perianal fistulas.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 800.

questions.text: Which among the following investigations will help in arriving at a definitive diagnosis of carcinoma of pancreatic head?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Guided biopsy
 
  • Guided biopsy techniques, such as endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA) or percutaneous biopsy, provide tissue samples for histopathological examination.
  • These techniques allow for direct sampling of the pancreatic tissue, providing a definitive diagnosis of carcinoma of the pancreatic head.
  • Histopathological examination helps in assessing the tumor type, grade, and stage, which is crucial for planning appropriate treatment strategies.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1282.

questions.text: The best way to identify abdominal mass in congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is:
Calculate the GCS for a patient with a 25-year-old brain injury who has the following parameters: Disoriented, presence of eye opening in response to pain and ability to localize pain.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 11

Eye-opening in response to pain - E2
Disoriented (confused conversation) - V4
Localizing pain - M5
GCS, hence, would be 2+4+5 = 11

* [Extra Edge]: Glasgow Coma Scale and GCS-P score
 

The Glasgow Coma Scale provides a clinical index of the ‘overall’ acute impairment of brain function, or so called ‘conscious level’. When it was described, features of focal dysfunction such as brainstem signs were not incorporated and instead were intended to be assessed separately. Nevertheless, there have been views that indices or scores that combine an assessment of ‘conscious level’ and ‘brain stem’ function may have a useful place. In response, the GCS Pupils Score (GCS-P) was constructed to bring together information about a patient’s responsiveness as reflected in the GCS Score and the pupil reaction.

The GCS Score is derived by assigning notation to the level in each of the three subcomponents of the GCS and summing the results of a patient’s assessment. Further information on the GCS Score can be accessed. The Pupil Reactivity Score summarises Information about loss of pupil reactivity to light and is calculated as follows.

Pupils Unreactive to Light Pupil Reactivity Score
Both Pupils 2
One Pupil 1
Neither Pupil 0

The GCS-P is calculated by subtracting the Pupil Reactivity Score (PRS) from the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) total score:
* GCS-P = GCS - PRS


Fig: Revised Glasgow Coma Scale

GCS Score = (E[4] + V[5] + M[6]) = Best possible score 15; worst possible score 3

Reference: ATLS® Advanced Trauma Life Support®, American College of Surgeons, 10th Edition, Page No 110.

questions.text: Development of RET proto-oncogene is associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Medullary carcinoma thyroid
 
  • The development of the RET proto-oncogene is associated with medullary carcinoma thyroid.
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid is a rare form of thyroid cancer that arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid gland.
  • Mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, inherited or acquired, are strongly associated with the development of medullary carcinoma thyroid.
* [Extra Edge]: MEN syndromes



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1087.

questions.text: Cutoff for surgery in abdominal aortic aneurysm in asymptomatic pts:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 5.5cm
 
  • The cutoff size for surgical intervention in asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysms is generally accepted to be 5.5cm.
  • Once the aneurysm reaches this size or larger, the risk of rupture increases significantly, and the benefit of surgical repair outweighs the risks associated with surgery.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1017.

questions.text: Which muscles are impacted by De Quervain tenosynovitis
questions.solution:
• De Quervain tenosynovitis, also known as washerwoman's sprain/strain, is a painful stenosing tenosynovitis involving the first extensor (dorsal) tendon compartment of the wrist (typically at the radial styloid).
  • This compartment contains the abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) tendons.
  • De Quervain tenosynovitis, the tendons become inflamed and irritated as they pass through this narrow tunnel, causing pain and discomfort in the thumb and wrist.

questions.text:
The patient experienced discomfort and edoema at the same location where he had an RTA two years prior.

questions.text: Which of the numbered bones in the X-ray given below gets fractured most frequently when an elderly person falls on their outstretched hands?

questions.text: Fallen fragment sign:
questions.solution:
• The fallen fragment sign refers to the presence of a bone fracture fragment resting dependently in a cystic bone lesion. 
  • This finding was once thought to be pathognomonic for a simple (unicameral) bone cyst following a pathological fracture, although it has occasionally been reported with other cystic lesions, e.g. eosinophilic granuloma or aneurysmal bone cyst 4.
  • The finding exists because a simple bone cyst is fluid-filled, and therefore a bony fragment may descend through the fluid uninhibited.

questions.text: You have been hired as a causality intern. Which of the following patients with fractures will you call ortho PG and tell as a top priority
questions.solution:

  • A 10 cm abrasion, for example, may require medical attention, but it is not an emergency. Similarly, the inability to extend the arm or an elbow dislocation can be serious injuries, but they are not immediately life-threatening and can wait for a short while before receiving medical attention.

questions.text: Which type of cells is prominently prevalent in joints of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Macrophages
 
  • Macrophages are responsible for engulfing and destroying foreign invaders, such as bacteria and viruses. 
  • In rheumatoid arthritis, macrophages are activated and become overactive. They produce inflammatory chemicals that damage the lining of the joints, leading to pain, swelling, and stiffness.
  • B cells, T cytotoxic cells, and dendritic cells are also involved in the immune response to rheumatoid arthritis, but they are not as prominently prevalent in the joints as macrophages





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2755-2757.

questions.text: Which sort of joint is made up of the 8th and 9th rib costal cartilage
questions.solution:
• The eighth, ninth, and tenth ribs form interchondral joints between their costal cartilages. The costochondral joints are formed between the end of the rib and the lateral edge of the costal cartilage.
  • The joint formed is cartilaginous, its perichondrium being continuous with the periosteum of the rib itself.
  • The interchondral joints are small articulations between the apposed costal cartilages of the ribs 7-10.
  • On each side are three diminutibetween the surfaces of the 6th and 7th costal cartilages, 7th and 8th costal cartilages and 8th and 9th costal cartilages.

Reference : Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,41st Edition - page no.940

questions.text: What is Tom Smith's septic arthritis
questions.solution:

questions.text: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by which enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT)

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome is an X linked recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase ( HGPRT )
HGPRT is responsible for generation of purine nucleotides such as IMP/GMP from bases such as hypoxanthine/guanine via purine salvage pathway.
As a result, purines accumulate resulting in increased degradation and generation of uric acid leading to hyperuricemia.

Clinically manifests as-
  • Self mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Intellectual disability
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Gout
Remember- Partial deficiency of HGPRTase results in Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 301.

questions.text: Which vaccine does Mission Indradhanush not include at the national level
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Japanese Encephalitis
  • Intensified Mission Indradhanush includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 diseases that Mission Indradhanush focussed on).
  • 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month).
  • The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are: TB, Polio , Hep B, Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Measles, Japanese Encephalitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis included in the Indradhanush Mission but it is not a nationally-notifiable disease in India so given only in endemic areas .
  • This means that there is not enough data to show that Japanese Encephalitis is a major public health problem in India.
  • However, the Mission Indradhanush does provide vaccines against Japanese Encephalitis in selected districts/states of the country where the disease is endemic.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 508.

questions.text: Which condition is depicted in the MRI T1 WI image below?

questions.text: How is shoulder dystocia treated?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Supra pubic pressure 
  • The McRoberts maneuver is often selected first. With it, legs are lifted from stirrups, hips are sharply flexed up onto the abdomen, and knees remain flexed. 
  • During McRoberts maneuver, an assistant can apply downward and laterally directed suprapubic pressure.
  • Head and neck should be grasped and taken posteriorly while suprapubic pressure is applied by an assistant slightly toward the side of fetal chest.
  • This will reduce the bisacromial diameter and rotate the anterior shoulder toward the oblique diameter. This maneuver is simple as well as effective. It needs only one assistant.

Management of Shoulder Dystocia (HELPERR Mnemonic)

  1. H – Help: Call for assistance.
  2. E – Evaluate for Episiotomy: Not always needed but may help.
  3. L – Legs (McRoberts Maneuver): Sharp flexion of maternal hips to the abdomen to widen the pelvic outlet (Option 1).
  4. P – Pressure (Suprapubic Pressure): Manual pressure applied above the pubic symphysis to push the fetal shoulder downward and dislodge it (Correct answer - Option 2).
  5. E – Enter (Internal Rotation Maneuvers - Rubin/Woods Screw Maneuver): Rotate the fetus’s shoulder by 90 degrees (related to Option 3 but not for the posterior shoulder).
  6. R – Remove Posterior Arm: Deliver the posterior shoulder first to reduce the shoulder width.
  7. R – Roll the patient (Gaskin Maneuver): Turn the mother to all fours to facilitate delivery.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 501-504.

questions.text: Which of the following levels changes the most throughout pregnancy:
questions.solution:
• Renal clearance of iodine is increased due to increased glomerular filtration. Maternal serum iodine levels fall due to increased renal loss and also due to transplacental shift to the fetus. These cause hyperplasia of the gland. Iodine intake during pregnancy should be increased from 100 !g/day to 200 !g/day (as recommended by WHO).
  • There is rise in the basal metabolic rate, which begins at about the third month, reaches a value of +25% during the last trimester. The increase in BMR is probably due to increase in net oxygen consumption of mother and fetus. There is stimulatory effect of hCG (chorionic thyrotropin) to thyroid gland mainly in the first trimester.
  • Due to this thyrotropic effect of hCG, there may be a transient phase of hyperthyroidism in some women (gestational transient thyrotoxicosis).
  • The serum protein-bound iodine is increased in pregnancy, the range being 6.2–11.2 microg% instead of the usual 4–8 microg%.
  • Thyroxin-binding globulin (TBG) increases and reaches a plateau by 20 weeks. It remains unchanged at that level until delivery. The increase in TBG is due to estrogen stimulation. Iodine and drugs used to treat hyperthyroidism cross the placenta freely.
  • Maternal total T4 and T3 are increased by 18 weeks but free T4 and T3 levels are unchanged.
  • Maternal TSH remains normal. Secretion of T4 and T3 is 20:1, but biological activity of T3 is five times more than that of T4.
  • Level of calcitonin — a thyroid hormone secreted by the parafollicular cells, increases by 20%. Calcitonin protects the maternal skeleton from excess bone loss during pregnancy and lactation.
  • Routine screening of all pregnant women for thyroid function is not recommended by ACOG. However women with high risk factors should have their serum TSH level checked in their first antenatal visit.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 71, 72.

Fertilization of two or more ova in different intercourses in same menstrual cycle is called Superfecundation.

questions.text: The most preferred anaesthesia for a pregnant patient with severe pre-eclampsia undergoing caesarean section is:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Epidural
 
  • Continuous epidural anesthesia is typically preferred for most patients with preeclampsia during labor, vaginal delivery, and cesarean sections.
  • Patients with preeclampsia are at risk of severe airway edema, which complicates intubation. Therefore, continuous epidural anesthesia is beneficial as it eliminates the need for intubation. Additionally, it can enhance uteroplacental perfusion and reduce catecholamine release.
  • However, a key requirement for regional anesthesia in preeclamptic patients is having a normal platelet count and normal coagulation. Coagulopathy is a contraindication for regional anesthesia. The minimum platelet count for regional anesthesia is generally 100,000/µL, though some cases may be managed with a count as low as 70,000/µL.
  • General anesthesia is recommended for patients with coagulopathy or severe preeclampsia with complications. Spinal anesthesia may be used in cases of mild preeclampsia, but its application is limited in moderate to severe preeclampsia due to the risk of hypotension associated with spinal anesthesia.
However, this is a controversial question. Preferred answer is Epidural> Spinal.


Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology, 5th edition, Page no 866.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in management of hypertension during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Table 2. Medications for Hypertensive Disorders of Pregnancy
Drug Dose Effects
Methyldopa 250 mg PO BID up to 1,000 mg PO every 8 hours (3,000 mg total daily dose) Agent with greatest available data in pregnancy and followup of offspring; limited by maternal dizziness, fatigue.
Labetalol 100 mg PO BID up to 800 mg PO every 8 hours, 10-80 mg IV for BP \(\geq\)160/110 (2,400 mg total daily dose) First line for acute hypertensive crisis; uteroplacental flow mostly unaffected; no fetal growth impairment in contrast to atenolol, propranolol.
Nifedipine  Short-acting: 10 mg PO every 8 hrs.; extended release: 30-90 mg PO qd (120 mg total daily dose) Short-acting use preferable; rapid vasodilation/hypotension; pregnancy data limited.
Hydralazine  10 mg PO every 6 hours up to 50 mg PO every 60 hours, 2.5-10 mg IV for BP>=160/110 (200 mg total daily dose) Consider for acute hypertensive crisis; note delayed onset, reflex tachycardia, flushing, headache. 
ACE inhibitors/ Angiotensin Receptor Blockers Any dosage Contraindicated, adverse fetal effects in later gestation.

questions.text: Modified Mallampati grading is used to evaluate:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Difficult intubation
 
  • Modified Mallampati grading is a classification system used to predict the difficulty of endotracheal intubation based on the visualization of the oral cavity and the extent to which the base of the tongue obstructs the view of the larynx.
  • It assesses the structures within the oral cavity, including the soft palate, uvula, fauces, and visibility of the tonsillar pillars.

  • The most commonly assessed nerve-muscle unit is the ulnar nerve-adductor pollicis muscle. 
  • This is because it is easily accessible, has the lowest risk of direct muscle stimulation, and the response can be evaluated visually, by tactile methods, or by objective methods.

questions.text: Identify the following circuit:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Mapleson A.
 
  • The circuit shown in the illustration is Mapleson A, also known as the Magill circuit.
  • The Mapleson A circuit is a rebreathing circuit used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.
  • It allows the patient to breathe spontaneously during the procedure, providing better control over ventilation and maintaining adequate oxygenation.
  •  It has a spring-loaded pop-off valve near the facemask. Gas enters the circuit opposite the side of the patient. It is best for allowing spontaneous breathing but worst for controlled ventilation. 
The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is A > DFE > CB.
The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A.






Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 611-613.

Correct option is 1: Cold temperature.
  • Cutis marmorata is a benign finding in a newborn. It refers to the pinkish-blue mottled or marbled appearance of skin (reticular pattern) due to dilatation of superficial capillaries and veins that occur due to cooler surrounding temperature.

questions.text: The image depicts a child who has a rash. His family has a history of asthma. What is the most likely medical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Atopic dermatitis
 
  • Atopic dermatitis is the cutaneous expression of the atopic state, characterized by a family history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, or eczema.
  • In infants, it presents as erythema and edematous papule in the face and extensor aspect of the knees and elbows. The papules are intensely itchy and may become exudative and crusted as a result of rubbing.
  • The epidermal barrier is impaired due to a mutation in the gene encoding filaggrin (a structural protein in the stratum corneum).
  • The site of lesions shifts to elbow and knee flexures when the child is 18 months to 2 years.
  • There is also a mixture of erythema, crusting, excoriation, hyper- and hypopigmentation, and warty lichenification seen on the sides of the neck, wrists, and ankles. 
Other features of atopic dermatitis include xerosis (dry skin), ichthyosis (fish-like scaly skin), and headlight sign (facial eczema sparing periorbital, perinasal, and perioral area).



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 41.16

questions.text: The following dye is used to diagnose esophageal perforation:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Iohexol • Non-ionic monomeric iodinated contrast material available by the trade name of Omnipaque.
• Compared to barium, less irritable to periesophageal tissue and is readily re-absorbed.
• In suspected esophageal perforation, administered as oral swallow following which under fluoroscopic/CT guidance, site of rent/perforation along with active leak can be demonstrated.
Option B- Gadolinium is an intravenous MRI contrast medium. Gadolinium causes shortening of T1 relaxation time owing to its paramagnetic property and hence, appears bright on T1W MRI. It is not used for diagnosis of esophageal perforation.
Option C- Barium is absolutely contraindication in esophageal perforation as barium can leak through the site of perforation and cause chemical mediastinitis and peritonitis.
Option D- SF6 is a contrast agent used in ultrasound. It has no role in diagnosing esophageal pathologies.


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 483.

questions.text: The Bragg peak effect can be seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Proton


 
  • The given graphical image demonstrates Bragg Peak effect seen with heavy and charged particles such as alpha particles and protons.
  • It shows dose delivered on Y-axis with increasing depth in the patient’s body on X-axis.
  • The dose delivered in case of protons and alpha particles is inversely proportional to their velocity in tissues.
  • At the site of entry, velocity is maximum, so dose deposited is minimum but at a certain depth where velocity is minimum, dose deposited is maximum forming a sudden sharp peak of exposure. This is called Bragg Peak effect.
  • Therefore, if tumor is localized at this depth, precise dose delivery to the tumor can be achieved.
  • Brag Peak effect finds its fundamental role in proton beam therapy wherein it allows higher dose gradients to be delivered to the tumor and reduced dose to adjacent organs at risk (OARs) .
  • Used in treatment of tumors close to critical organs such as esophagus, spinal cord, head, and brachial plexus. 


Reference: Walter & Miller's Textbook of Radiotherapy, 7th edition, Page no 28, 29.

questions.text: An MRI of the skull shows:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Vein of Galen malformation.
 



Vein of Galen malformation:
  • Congenital malformation of the intracranial circulation characterized by an enlarged midline venous structure (persistent embryological remnant of median prosencephalic vein) with multiple arteriovenous communications leading to aneurysmal dilatation. 
  • It constitutes one of the causes of pediatric stroke. 
  • Clinical presentation: 
    • Neonates- Severe cardiac failure
    • Infants- Due to smaller degree of shunting, cardiac failure is uncommon. Present with hydrocephalus and cerebral atrophy.
    • Older children-Headache, seizures, intracerebral or subarachnoid hemorrhage. 
Radiological features: 
  • CT- Parenchymal calcification secondary to chronic venous hypertension
  • MRI- Investigation of choice. It demonstrates
    • Dilated venous sac
    • Location of fistulous connections
    • Feeding arteries 
    • Draining veins 
    • Extent of parenchymal damage in the form of infarction/atrophy. 
  • Angiography- Gold standard. Diagnostic as well as therapeutic 

Other options: -



Pneumocephalus 

Crouzon syndrome is a type of cranial synostosis

questions.text: What degrades Trilene?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Enzymatic Degradation
 
  • Naturally occurring bacteria have the ability to degrade TRILENE / TRICHLOROETHYLENE
  •  In Anaerobic conditions: - Trichloroethylene can be degraded by reductive dichlorination
  • Aerobic conditions: - Pseudomonas can metabolize TCE using the enzyme Toluene Dioxygenase
  • Four main biodegradation processes leading to TCE biodegradation by isolated bacteria and mixed cultures are anaerobic reductive dechlorination, anaerobic cometabolic reductive dichlorination, aerobic co-metabolism, and aerobic direct oxidation. 
Online Reference: Wu Z, Man Q, Niu H, Lyu H, Song H, Li R, Ren G, Zhu F, Peng C, Li B, Ma X. Recent advances and trends of trichloroethylene biodegradation: A critical review. Front Microbiol. 2022 Dec 22;13:1053169. doi: 10.3389/fmicb.2022.1053169. PMID: 36620007; PMCID: PMC9813602.

questions.text: What is the first sign of third cranial nerve involvement in a person with diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Normal light reflex.
 
  • Acquired oculomotor nerve palsy can have various causes, and if a patient presents with specific symptoms such as ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, and mydriasis, it is important to rule out a compressive etiology such as an intracranial aneurysm.
  • The pupillary fibers within the oculomotor nerve are located peripherally and have better collateral blood supply, making them more susceptible to compression. The most common cause in such cases is a posterior communicating artery aneurysm.
  • However, if a patient has a complete or incomplete oculomotor palsy without pupil involvement (pupil-sparing 3rd nerve palsy), it is more likely to be related to ischemic processes, although compression and inflammation should still be considered as potential causes.
  • Pupillary fibers, being more peripheral, are less vulnerable to ischemia.
  • Diabetes is an ischemic rather than a compressive pathology and hence pupil sparing occurs.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3125.
Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page 799.

Which of the following is not a special visceral efferent column?
questions.solution:
The option that is not a special visceral efferent (SVE) column is 4. nucleus ambiguous.

While the nucleus ambiguous contains neurons that give rise to SVE fibers of the glossopharyngeal (IX) and vagus (X) nerves, it itself is a nucleus rather than a cranial nerve. The trigeminal (V), glossopharyngeal (IX), and vagus (X) nerves are all involved in SVE functions.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent illnesses is NOT caused on by parvovirus B19?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Roseola infantum

Roseola infantum, also known as sixth disease or exanthema subitum, is not caused by parvovirus B19. It is typically caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) or, less commonly, human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7).

On the other hand, parvovirus B19 is associated with the following conditions:
 
  1. Aplastic anemia in sickle cell disease: Parvovirus B19 infection can cause transient aplastic crisis in individuals with underlying hemolytic conditions such as sickle cell disease. It can lead to a temporary shutdown of red blood cell production, resulting in anemia.
  2. Fetal hydrops: Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to severe complications in the fetus, including fetal hydrops. Fetal hydrops is a condition characterized by abnormal fluid accumulation in two or more fetal compartments, such as the skin, abdomen, or thorax.
  3. Erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease): This is a common childhood illness caused by parvovirus B19. It is characterized by a distinctive rash on the face, giving a "slapped cheek" appearance, followed by a lacy rash on the trunk and limbs.







Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 27th edition, Page no 441, 443, 459.

  • The iliolumbar ligament is a strong band of fibrous tissue that connects the iliac crest to the transverse process of L5 and the base of the sacrum.
  • It helps to stabilize the lumbosacral joint and prevent excessive movement of the lumbar spine.
  • The iliolumbar ligament does not have an attachment to the transverse process of T12 (twelfth thoracic vertebra). Instead, its upper attachment is to the posterior part of the iliac crest, as mentioned in statement A.
  • The lower fibers are attached to the base of the sacrum.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most commonly linked to congenital adrenal hyperplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 2. Female pseudohermaphroditism
 
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) most often appears as female pseudohermaphroditism, with the most common enzyme deficiency being 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • A female pseudohermaphrodite is a genetically typical female (46, XX) whose external genitalia resemble those of a male.
 
  • Children with 21-hydroxylase deficiency typically present between 10 and 14 days of age with a range of symptoms resulting from aldosterone deficiency, cortisol deficiency, and androgen excess.
  • Aldosterone deficiency leads to salt-wasting crises, characterized by hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis. Cortisol deficiency results in symptoms such as hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation, weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, and shock.
 
  • Androgen excess in 21-hydroxylase deficiency causes virilization in females, leading to female pseudohermaphroditism, and precocious puberty in males. In females, virilization is typically noticeable at birth, while in males, it becomes apparent by 2 to 3 years of age. Without treatment, severe complications such as shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.

Other options:
 
  • Option 1: Male pseudohermaphroditism is seen in CAH due to 17α-hydroxylase deficiency, which leads to incomplete virilization. This is the second most common enzyme deficiency in CAH.
  • Option 3: True hermaphroditism, now called ovotesticular disorder of sex development (DSD), involves the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue and is not related to CAH.
  • Option 4: 46 XY intersex (now termed 46 XY DSD) involves under-virilization of the genitalia. Adrenal causes include lipoid adrenal hyperplasia, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency, and 17-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase deficiency, but not 21-hydroxylase deficiency.




Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 2973, 2974, 2977, 3025.

questions.text: A diabetic patient experiences hypopyon two days after having cataract surgery. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Intravitreal antibiotics.
 
  • Hypopyon is a purulent whitish exudate consisting of inflammatory cells in the inferior part of the anterior chamber. 
  • In a diabetic patient who develops hypopyon after cataract surgery, there is a higher risk of infection due to the compromised immune response and delayed wound healing associated with diabetes. So, it warrants a severe form of intra-ocular inflammation called Endophthalmitis.
  • The next step would be to administer intravitreal antibiotics.
  • Intravitreal antibiotics are injected directly into the vitreous cavity of the eye and provide targeted treatment for intraocular infections.
  • This approach allows for a higher concentration of antibiotics to reach the infection site, providing a more effective treatment compared to eye drops alone.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 725, 727.

questions.text: According to the ISNT rule, which is the thinnest portion of the neuro-retinal rim?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Temporal.
 
  • The ISNT rule is used to describe the thickness of the neuro-retinal rim. The neuro-retinal rim refers to the portion of the optic nerve head that surrounds the cup, which is the central depression in the optic disc. This pattern of rim width is known as the ISNT rule (inferior > superior > nasal > temporal).
  • The “ISNT rule” (which states that, in a normal eye, the neuroretinal rim width follows a characteristic pattern of Inferior ≥ Superior ≥ Nasal ≥ Temporal) may be helpful as a general principle to differentiate normal from glaucomatous nerves.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1032.

questions.text: Which of the following has a mutational deficit and leads to Leiden thrombophilia?

questions.text: Which of the following structures is formed by the dorsal mesentery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Greater omentum
  • The structure formed by the dorsal mesentery is the Greater omentum.
  • The dorsal mesentery is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the posterior abdominal wall and connects to various abdominal organs during embryonic development.
  • The Greater omentum is a part of the dorsal mesentery and is formed by its two layers.
  • It is a large, apron-like fold of peritoneum that hangs down from the greater curvature of the stomach, covering the small intestines.
  • The Greater omentum plays a role in protecting and insulating the abdominal organs and may also assist in limiting the spread of infection within the abdominal cavity.

questions.text: According to the following X-ray, what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Bladder stones.


 
  • Bladder calculi/bladder stones.
  • Comprise ~ 5% of all urinary tract stones. 
  • Divided into primary, secondary, and migratory stones:
    • Primary: bladder stones seen in absence of other urinary tract abnormality
    • Secondary: Stones formed in an abnormal bladder or from concretions on foreign material (e.g. urinary catheters)
    • Migratory: Renal calculi which have migrated down into the bladder
Radiographic features:
 
  • Plain radiograph

questions.text: Which mechanism does a virus or viral vector use to deliver foreign DNA into a cell?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Transduction

Transduction is known as the transfer of a portion of the DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage.
Other options- Transcription – This is the process by which information in DNA is copied to RNA for the coding of proteins.
Lysogenic conversion- Here, the phage DNA becomes integrated with the bacterial chromosome as the prophage, which multiplies along with the host DNA and is transferred to the daughter cells.
Transformation- It is the process of transfer of genetic information through the agency of free DNA.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 59.

questions.text: Which of the following is present in rheumatoid arthritis seropositive patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: All

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disease primarily affecting the joints. Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refers to the presence of certain autoantibodies, particularly rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies, in the blood of affected individuals.

In seropositive rheumatoid arthritis, patients typically exhibit the following characteristics:
  1. Multiple joints affected: Rheumatoid arthritis commonly affects multiple joints throughout the body. Small joints of the hands, wrists, and feet are frequently involved, but larger joints can also be affected.
  2. Symmetrical joint symptoms: The joint involvement in rheumatoid arthritis is usually symmetrical, meaning that if a joint on one side of the body is affected, the corresponding joint on the other side will likely be affected as well.
  3. Joint pain and swelling: Joint pain and swelling are hallmark symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis. The affected joints may be tender, warm to the touch, and show signs of inflammation.

Here's a table listing the common patterns of joint involvement in Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA):

 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2751, 2752, 2759.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the anterior mediastinum?
Which metal ion is the component of struvite?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) both (a) & (b)

Struvite stones are made up of Magnesium Ammonium Phosphate (struvite) along with Calcium-Carbonate/Phosphate/Apatite.
Struvite(mineral) by itself refers to only Magnesium Ammonium Phosphate but in the human body, the struvite stones formation usually involves both Magnesium Ammonium Phosphate(struvite) along with Calcium-Carbonate/Phosphate/Apatite.

* Struvite Stones:

They are also known as triple phosphate(due to three cations - Mg2+/Ca2+ and NH4+ ) and Infection stones since they are commonly seen in UTIs by urease-producing organisms (eg Proteus mirabilis).
Urease splits urea into Ammonia and H2O and the increased ammonia production causes the urine pH to get elevated, which decreases the solubility of phosphate and leads to the precipitation of Magnesium Ammonium Phosphate.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1762.

questions.text: Which of the following given below stimulates the secretion of aldosterone?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Hyperkalemia Hyperkalemia is the most potent stimulus for aldosterone secretion as the major function of aldosterone is Na+ and water reabsorption and K+ excretion Regulators of aldosterone secretion ACTH stimulated Glucorticoids secretion and occasionally it is also reported to stimulate aldosterone secretion, although its effects on aldosterone under normal conditions are minimal compared with those of potassium and others Both endogenous and exogenous glucocorticoids exert negative feedback effects on both pituitary and hypothalamus levels. This negative feedback effect of exogenous glucocorticoid administration can lead to secondary adrenal insufficiency. Hypernatremia suppresses aldosterone release to prevent further Na+ and water reabsorption.

choices.text: One in 10 people age 65 and older has Alzheimer’s disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Alzheimer's disease is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Alzheimer’s disease is curable.
 
  • The incorrect statement is B. Alzheimer's disease is curable.
  • Alzheimer's disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that causes memory loss, cognitive decline, and behavioral changes.
  • Currently, there is no cure for Alzheimer's disease, but various treatments and interventions can help manage symptoms and slow down its progression.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3370.

choices.text: Prolong use of antimicrobial leads to deficiency

questions.text: Which of the following statements about vitamin K is true?
questions.solution:
Vit K is a Fat soluble vitamin which is responsible for synthesis of Clotting factors 2,7,9,10. It is synthesized within the body by the gut flora. Antimicrobials can kill the good flora along with the bad bacteria and can their prolonged use can cause Vit K deficiency.

  • Anticoagulant:

    • False. Vitamin K is essential for the synthesis of clotting factors (e.g., Factors II, VII, IX, and X). It actually supports blood coagulation, not anticoagulation.

  • Prolong use of antimicrobial leads to deficiency:

    • True. Antimicrobials can disrupt gut bacteria, which produce vitamin K, leading to a deficiency over time.

  • Dietary allowance is 15-20 mg:

    • False. The recommended daily allowance (RDA) for vitamin K is much lower, typically 90-120 µg (micrograms) for adults, depending on age and gender.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 532.

questions.text: Which medications require ongoing prothrombin time monitoring?

questions.text: Which of the following is a cutaneous lymphoma risk factor?
Which of the following is not included in the AIDS-related complex?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ectopic pregnancy
 
  • AIDS-related complex (ARC) refers to a condition characterized by symptoms and signs that are less severe than those seen in full-blown AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome).
  • It is considered an earlier stage of HIV infection. The features typically seen in ARC include recurrent infections, generalized lymphadenopathy, chronic diarrhea, weight loss, fever, fatigue, and night sweats.
  • Ectopic pregnancy is a separate medical condition unrelated to the immune status of an individual. Therefore, is not included in the AIDS-related complex.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1527, 1540-1543.

questions.text: Which procedure is preferred for irradiation of the chordoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Protons
 
  • Proton irradiation is the preferred procedure for irradiating chordomas.
  • Proton therapy utilizes protons, which are charged particles, to deliver radiation to the tumor with high precision.
  • Proton beams have the advantage of depositing most of their energy within the tumor, minimizing radiation exposure to surrounding healthy tissues.
  • This targeted approach helps spare critical structures, such as the spinal cord and nearby organs, reducing the risk of complications and optimizing treatment outcomes.
  • Compared to other radiation techniques like electrons, gamma radiation, or 3D-CRT (three-dimensional conformal radiation therapy), proton therapy offers superior control and accuracy in treating chordomas.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 776.

questions.text: Where are Reed Sternberg cells found?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hodkin's Disease
 
  • Reed-Sternberg cells are considered Pathognomic/typical of Hodgkin's lymphoma.
  • They are distinct neoplastic giant cells (30-60 um in size) with abundant cytoplasm, 2 large nuclei, and 2 large inclusion like nucleoli giving an Owl Eye appearance that stimulate reactive lymphocytes, histiocytes (macrophages), and granulocytes to assemble in large numbers.
  • Reed Sternberg cells in a background of inflammatory cells infiltrate are diagnostic of Hodgkin's Lymphoma. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 611.

questions.text: A patient who is confined to a bed feels severe chest discomfort that is made worse by breathing. Which imaging techniques might be helpful?
Chordoma arises from which of the following options given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Notochord
 
  • Chordoma is a rare type of cancer.
  • It arises from remnants of the notochord, an embryonic structure present during early development.
  • The notochord is a flexible, rod-like structure that forms along the central axis of the developing embryo.
  • During normal development, the notochord is replaced by the vertebral column (spine) in most parts of the body.
  • However, small remnants of the notochord can persist at certain sites, particularly in the region of the base of the skull and the sacrococcygeal area (near the tailbone).
  • Chordoma occurs when these remnants of the notochord give rise to abnormal growths or tumors.
  • These tumors most commonly occur in the skull base or the sacrum (the triangular bone at the base of the spine)
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 567

questions.text: Which metal causes the development of "Saturnine gout"?

Chronic lead poisoning is known as Plumbism or Saturnism

  • Seen in workers of paint, pipe, pottery petrol factories.
  • Clinical features:
    • Anemia
    • Burtonian lines
    • Basophilic strippling

questions.text: Which of the following deficiencies causes phenylketonuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Phenylalanine hydroxylase ( PAH)
 
  • Autosomal recessive disorder of phenylalanine metabolism which occurs due to deficiency of enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase.
  • Clinical features-
  • Mental retardation
  • Seizures, hyperactivity and tremors
  • Microcephaly
  • Fair hair, light skin color and blue eyes due to deficiency of pigmentation.
  • Screening tests-

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect:
Maastricht classification of donation after cardiac death. What category is stage 3 ?
Other than MI, what are the causes of myocardial shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: All of the above

Myocardial shock, also known as cardiogenic shock, is a severe condition characterized by inadequate circulation of blood due to the heart's inability to pump effectively. While acute myocardial infarction (MI) is a common cause of myocardial shock, other conditions can also lead to this condition.
  1. Acute mitral regurgitation: Severe acute mitral regurgitation can result in a sudden increase in left ventricular volume and pressure overload. This can lead to a decrease in cardiac output and ultimately result in myocardial shock.
  2. Ventricular septal rupture: Ventricular septal rupture is a complication that can occur after an MI. It involves a rupture in the septum that separates the ventricles of the heart. This condition leads to a significant shunting of blood between the ventricles, compromising cardiac output and causing myocardial shock.
  3. Isolated right ventricular shock: Isolated right ventricular shock refers to a condition where the right ventricle fails to pump blood effectively. It can occur due to various causes, such as right ventricular infarction, severe pulmonary embolism, or right heart failure. In this condition, there is a decrease in systemic cardiac output, resulting in myocardial shock.
Therefore, all of the listed options can contribute to the development of myocardial shock by compromising the heart's ability to pump blood effectively.



Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1148.

questions.text: A boy with sickle cell anemia and non-suppurative osteomyelitis appeared. What will be the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Salmonella

Sickle cell anemia is a genetic blood disorder characterized by the presence of abnormal sickle-shaped red blood cells. Individuals with sickle cell anemia are more susceptible to infections, including osteomyelitis, due to impaired blood flow and compromised immune function.

Among the options provided:
  1. Salmonella: Salmonella is a common cause of osteomyelitis in individuals with sickle cell anemia. Salmonella osteomyelitis tends to affect the long bones, particularly the femur and tibia.
  2. S. aureus (Staphylococcus aureus): While S. aureus is a common cause of osteomyelitis in the general population, it is less frequently associated with osteomyelitis in individuals with sickle cell anemia.
  3. H. influenzae (Haemophilus influenzae): H. influenzae is primarily associated with respiratory tract infections and meningitis. It is not a common causative organism for osteomyelitis.
  4. Enterobacter species: Enterobacter species are not typically associated with osteomyelitis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1297.

questions.text: How does colchicine work to treat acute gout?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Inhibits neutrophilic migration
 
  • Colchicine works to treat acute gout by inhibiting neutrophilic migration, which is the movement of white blood cells (neutrophils) to the site of inflammation caused by the accumulation of uric acid crystals in the joint. This inhibition reduces the inflammatory response in the affected area and thus helps to alleviate pain, swelling, and tenderness.
  • Colchicine does not inhibit urate oxidase, xanthine oxidase, or cyclooxygenase, which are enzymes involved in the production of uric acid or inflammation. Allopurinol inhibits Xanthine oxidase while NSAIDs inhibit cyclooxygenase.
  • Colchicine is considered a second-line treatment for acute gout, used when nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or corticosteroids are ineffective, contraindicated, or not tolerated.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 231.

questions.text: Which conditions may not benefit from oxygen therapy?
questions.solution:
• The interstitial lung diseases (ILDs) are characterised by scarring and fibrosis of lung tissue with varying degrees of hypoxaemia. Common symptoms include severe cough and dyspnea.
  • Despite recent advances in pharmacotherapy, many patients with ILD have limited treatment options.
  • Oxygen therapy is commonly prescribed for people with ILD, with the aim of reducing breathlessness and increasing physical capacity through improved gas exchange. Despite its frequent use there is a lack of evidence supporting the effectiveness of oxygen therapy in ILD.
  • Supplemental oxygen users with pulmonary fibrosis perceive greater dyspnea than oxygen non-users.
  • Many systematic reviews showed no effects of oxygen therapy on dyspnea during exercise in ILD, although exercise capacity was increased.



Reference: Oxygen therapy for interstitial lung disease: a systematic review, Emily C. Bell, Narelle S. Cox, Nicole Goh, Ian Glaspole, Glen P. Westall, Alice Watson, Anne E. Holland, European Respiratory Review Mar 2017, 26 (143) 160080; DOI: 10.1183/16000617.0080-2016. URL: https://err.ersjournals.com/content/26/143/160080

questions.text: What among the following cannot be used to revive a newborn baby whose heart rate is less than 60 beats per minute?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 4: Slapping the back
  • According to the Neonatal Resuscitation Protocol, flicking the soles is done after the initial assessment of term, tone, and cry if the baby does not cry immediately. Slapping the back is NOT recommended.
  • If in term infants there are no improvements or the HR is <100 beats/min after stimulation, positive pressure ventilation using a bag and mask is provided.
  • If there is still no rise in HR, corrective ventilatory efforts MRSOPA should be taken.
  • If the HR falls below 60 in spite of corrective steps then the patient is intubated and given chest compressions, and 100% Oxygen. If the patient still doesn’t respond, IV epinephrine is given.



 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 126-133

Should be Done by single layer serosal sutures

questions.text:
A 6-year-old kid who was in life-threatening shock had a CT scan that revealed significant ascites, thickening of the gut wall,
and poor or no enhancement of the strangulated bowel segment, which on surgical exploration revealed a gangrenous intestine.
What is accurate about anastomosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Should be done using single layer extra mucosal technique
 
  • When performing an anastomosis for a gangrenous intestine, it is important to ensure a secure and watertight connection.
  • The preferred technique is to perform a single-layer anastomosis taking the submucosa.
  • This technique allows for proper alignment of the intestinal layers, ensuring adequate blood supply and reducing the risk of complications.
  • Additionally, using absorbable sutures made of materials like polyglactin or polydioxanone is commonly preferred over catgut (option C), as these materials provide better tensile strength and reduce the risk of suture-related complications.
  • Continuous layers (option A) are not necessary and can be time-consuming, while using absorbable sutures like catgut (option B) is not ideal for an anastomosis.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1306.

questions.text: In ACLS, which drug other than epinephrine can be given following ventricular fibrillation after cardiac arrest?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Amiodarone

Here is a simplified ACLS flowchart:
  1. Assess Responsiveness and Activate Emergency Response:
    • Check for responsiveness of the patient.
    • Activate the emergency response system, call for help, and obtain necessary equipment.
  2. Assess Airway, Breathing, and Circulation (ABCs):
    • Open the airway and check for breathing.
    • Check for the presence of a pulse.
    • If the patient is unresponsive, not breathing, or pulseless, start CPR immediately.
  3. Basic Life Support (BLS):
    • Perform high-quality chest compressions.
    • Provide rescue breaths (ventilation) using a bag-mask device or advanced airway as appropriate.
    • Minimize interruptions in chest compressions.
  4. Attach Monitor and Assess Rhythm:
    • Attach a cardiac monitor/defibrillator to assess the patient's cardiac rhythm.
    • Identify shockable rhythms (ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia).
  5. Defibrillation:
    • Deliver a shock using a defibrillator (if indicated) followed by immediate chest compressions.
  6. Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support:
    • Administer epinephrine promptly after the first shock.
    • Continue cycles of CPR (compressions and ventilations).
    • Assess the rhythm after each cycle of CPR.
    • Consider advanced airway management (endotracheal intubation) and capnography monitoring.
  7. Medications and Interventions:
    • Administer antiarrhythmic medications (such as amiodarone or lidocaine) if the patient remains in a shockable rhythm.
    • Treat specific causes of cardiac arrest if identified (e.g., treat reversible causes like hypoxia, hypovolemia, hypothermia, etc.).
    • Consider advanced interventions like transcutaneous pacing, intraosseous access, or central venous access as needed.
  8. Post-Cardiac Arrest Care:
    • Optimize ventilation and oxygenation.
    • Maintain hemodynamic stability.
    • Treat hypotension with fluids or vasopressors as necessary.
    • Targeted temperature management (hypothermia protocol) may be considered in selected patients.






Reference: Adult Cardiac Arrest algorithm, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 guidelines. URL: https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms
